awd_titl_txt: Development and Implementation of a Global Human Metabolic Physiology Database
awd_abstract_narration:
Daily total energy expenditure (TEE) is the total number of calories an individual burns each day. TEE measures are critically important for investigating fundamental questions about energy allocation, human physiology and adaptations, as well as for understanding how individual characteristics and lifestyle factors are related to common morbidities such as obesity and diabetes. However, TEE data are difficult to obtain and use given the expense of data collection and limited data accessibility across projects. This project will support the development of a freely accessible global database of over 10,000 TEE measurements, contributed by leading TEE laboratories in the U.S. and other countries. Making these TEE data openly available to researchers will advance science in biological anthropology, physiology, and public health. This project will also support training and education workshops, with outreach to underrepresented groups in STEM, to educate researchers in biological anthropology and related fields in current techniques and advances in metabolic research, and to foster synergistic research across basic and applied sciences in human biology and health. 

The database will house n=10,000+ measures of TEE and related data (anthropometrics and ecological variables) for populations around the globe. All TEE data are from doubly labeled water measurements, the gold standard for TEE. This project will use these data to test the effects of anthropometrics, reproductive status, and ecological factors on TEE. The online database and freely available R scripts will be developed to encourage and support use of the database by researchers worldwide. A workshop will be held to train researchers (especially early career and underrepresented groups) in modern methods of metabolic research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Energy expenditure, the calories our bodies burn each day, is central to biological anthropology, human physiology, and health. Energy requirements change as we grow and age, and vary across lifestyles and settings. Further, imbalances between the calories we consume and expend underlie obesity and related disease. However, research in human energy expenditure has been limited by access to large datasets for investigating its determinants and effects. Understanding the multitude of factors that affect energy expenditure requires large datasets with objectively measured expenditures for people across the lifespan and in a variety of settings. To advance the science of human metabolism, researchers also need to understand best practices and methods for investigating energy expenditure.

  This project supported the development of a large, international database with over 8,000 measurements of daily energy expenditure, with people from 8 days to over 90 years old, from more than 25 countries around the globe, including a broad range of lifestyles. The database is free to use and provides a unique and essential resource for scientists investigating energy expenditure (metabolism). Several studies from the database have already been published and more projects are underway. Analyses from the database are already reshaping our understanding of human metabolism and physiology, showing, for example, that energy expenditures are elevated during childhood, stable through adulthood, and then decline after age 60. Other analyses have shown that the body adjusts to differences in physical activity to maintain daily energy expenditures in a narrow range; that having a “fast” metabolism does not protect against weight gain; and that men have more variable metabolic rates than women. These findings and others will advance understanding in biological anthropology and physiology, and hold important implications for improving health.

  The project also supported an Energetics in Anthropology conference held at Duke University in May 2022. With over 70 attendees, the conference included talks and poster presentations on cutting edge research in human energy expenditure, current methods for measuring metabolic rates, and best practices for investigating expenditure and related variables in the lab and the field. The project supported 17 travel fellowships for early career researchers. By bringing together researchers from across the life sciences as well as from various subfields in biological anthropology, the conference helped to develop cross-disciplinary collaboration and advance the state of the science in human energetics.

 Intellectual Merit: Analyses from the energetics database have led to important advances in our understanding of the human body. For example, clear changes in metabolic rates (energy expenditure) with age revealed four “metabolic phase” of life that were previously unappreciated. The database has also enabled refinements in the methods used to calculate daily energy expenditures, improving the science of human metabolism into the future.

 Broader Impacts: Results from the energetics database impact current understanding of nutritional needs and other aspects of health. For example, the elevated energy expenditures evident in children may affect the time course of medications, and the slower metabolic rates in adults over 60 may lead to slower disease progression. Variability in metabolic rates, particularly among older adults, may reflect variation in the risk for age-related disease. With the database as a resource, future work will be able to investigate these and other directions.

  The Energetics in Anthropology conference led to new cross-disciplinary collaborations and expanded professional networks for researchers in biological anthropology and other life sciences fields. Further, the travel fellowships enabled 17 early career researchers to attend and participate, providing training in energetics methods and enhancing professional development.
